block.p: Correction of Data Shows Slightly Higher Inflation The government said that a software error caused it to slightly underestimate inflation during the first eight months of the year. Revision of the data means somewhat higher payments for recipients of Social Security and other federal benefits.

And while economists said that the error, one-tenth of a percentage point, was not large enough to significantly alter their view of the nation's economy, it was nonetheless in the direction of faster inflation. [Page C6.]

Northern Gas Pipelines Proposed Energy companies, pipeline operators and Indian tribes expect to announce next spring plans to build one, and possibly two, subterranean pipelines to carry Arctic natural gas to North America's pipeline grid. [A1.]

Priceline Drops on Sales Forecast Shares in the online retailer Priceline.com fell more than 40 percent after the company said its sales in the third quarter would be as much as 11 percent below forecasts. The company attributed the shortfall to slow sales of airline tickets -- its signature product, which still account for 87 percent of its sales. Shares of Priceline fell $7.89, to $10.75. [C10.]

Stocks Slump on Earnings Concern Stock prices fell as investors continued to be concerned about third-quarter results. The Dow Jones industrial average declined 2.96 points, to 10,628.36. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 32.80 points, or 0.9 percent, to 3,656.30. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 0.64 of a point, to 1,426.57. [C13.]

Audit Firm's Inspections Criticized In a report to be issued today, a professor contends that PricewaterhouseCoopers, the world's largest factory-monitoring firm, does a shoddy job and overlooks many safety and wage violations in plants overseas. Pricewaterhouse disputed the conclusions. [A12.]

FleetBoston in Talks to Buy Summit Summit Bancorp, the largest bank in New Jersey, is in talks to be acquired by FleetBoston Financial, executives close to the discussions said. Analysts estimated the bank could be sold for $7 billion. [C6.]

Sale of Global Crossing Unit Is Seen In a move that would advance its lead in the business of storage and maintenance facilities for Web sites, Exodus Communications is close to acquiring the Web-hosting division of Global Crossing for about $6.5 billion in stock, people close to the companies said. [C10.]

Interpublic Names a Coordinator Bruce S. Nelson, an executive with experience in the account, creative and strategic realms of advertising, is being named to a new top post at Interpublic Group. Mr. Nelson will coordinate efforts to manage the increasingly diversified Interpublic units specializing in interactive and direct marketing, public relations, media services, research, programming and consulting as well as traditional advertising. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C12.]

Judge Favors Release of Tire Data A federal judge ruled that the public should have access to extensive information on tire technology that Firestone had to turn over during a lawsuit over a fatal accident. The company said releasing the documents would amount to giving up trade secrets. [C2.]

Air France Sues in Concorde Crash Air France said that it had sued Continental Airlines because it believed a metal strip from a Continental DC-10 that fell onto a runway led to the crash of its Concorde jet in July. [A5.]

Government Still Has Economic Role George W. Bush has made government a campaign issue, arguing that as president he would continue to tame Washington. But the oversimplified fear of big government has been damaging. The next president should realize that both business and government have vital roles. Jeff Madrick: Economic Scene. [C2.]
